overview: The purpose of this Act is to establish an accessory dwelling unit financing and deed restriction program under the Hawaii housing finance and development corporation to promote the development of additional housing while securing that housing for local residents working in Hawaii. [14] The bill specifies eligible homeowners or homebuyers for the Program to finance construction costs, development costs, and non-reoccurring closing costs associated with the construction of an accessory dwelling unit and purchase deed restrictions on the property. [14] This Act shall be repealed on January 1, 2031, and section 6, relating to conveyance tax exemptions, shall take effect on January 1, 2026. [14] [13]
appropriations: The committee has amended this measure by appropriating an unspecified amount for fiscal year 2025-2026 into and out of the Dwelling Unit Revolving Fund for infrastructure projects. [15] The committee recommends an appropriation amount of $20,000,000 (HB740_SD2_SSCR1659_.htm.txt) into the Dwelling Unit Revolving Fund. [15] The sum appropriated shall be expended by the Hawaii housing finance and development corporation for the purposes of this Act. [14]
assumptions_and_methodology: The Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation notes that the ceiling of $2,000,000 (HB740_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) per year will limit the reach of the program. [13] Assuming that the average value of participating properties is $1,000,000 (HB740_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt), the cost of the deed restriction is $80,000 (HB740_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt), and $40,000 (HB740_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) of equity is provided for each ADU, the program will be able to enroll about 17 properties per year. [13]
agency_impact: The Department of Taxation (DOTAX) can administer the tax law changes in section 6 of the bill with the January 1, 2026, effective date. [13] Counties shall be responsible for validating the evidence and ensuring compliance with this subpart and may contract with non-government persons or entities to ensure compliance. [14] The Hawaii housing finance and development corporation shall submit a report of its evaluation of the program to the legislature no later than twenty days prior to the convening of the regular session of 2031. [14]
economic_impact: The Department of Taxation estimates a revenue loss to the General Fund as a result of the conveyance tax exemption in the bill. [13] The estimated revenue losses are ($0.9M) in FY 2026, ($1.9M) in FY 2027, ($2.0M) in FY 2028, ($2.1M) in FY 2029, ($2.2M) in FY 2030, and ($2.3M) in FY 2031. [13]
policy_impact: An action on a property with a deed restriction in place pursuant to this subpart shall be exempt from chapter 343 regarding environmental impact statements. [14] Property sold for which a county has purchased a deed restriction pursuant to this subpart shall be exempt from chapter 247 regarding conveyance tax. [14] Any contract entered into by a county pursuant to this subpart shall be exempt from chapter 103D, the procurement code. [14]
revenue_sources: An unspecified sum is appropriated out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii for fiscal year 2025-2026 to be deposited into the dwelling unit revolving fund. [14] The committee report recommends this amount to be $20,000,000 (HB740_SD2_SSCR1659_.htm.txt). [15] This appropriation is separate from the funding for the ADU equity purchase program, which is allocated from the rental housing revolving fund. [14]
six_year_fiscal_implications: The Department of Taxation (DOTAX) estimates a general fund revenue loss due to the conveyance tax exemption created in section 6 of the bill. [13] The estimated revenue loss is projected to be ($0.9M) in FY 2026. [13] For FY 2027, the estimated loss is ($1.9M). [13] In FY 2028, the estimated revenue loss is ($2.0M). [13] The estimated revenue loss for FY 2029 is ($2.1M). [13] For FY 2030, the loss is estimated to be ($2.2M). [13] The estimated revenue loss for FY 2031 is ($2.3M). [13] A separate appropriation for fiscal year 2025-2026 is recommended at $20,000,000 (HB740_SD2_SSCR1659_.htm.txt) from general revenues into the Dwelling Unit Revolving Fund for infrastructure projects. [15] [15] The corporation shall not allocate more than $2,000,000 (HB740_SD2_.HTM.txt) per year for the ADU financing program itself. [14] A homeowner participating in the purchase of equity shall repay the corporation its prorated share of the appraised value of the completed accessory dwelling unit, with appreciation, within fifteen years or upon sale or transfer of the property, whichever occurs first. [14]
operating_revenue_impact: The Department of Taxation (DOTAX) estimates a general fund revenue loss as a result of the measure. [13] The estimated loss ranges from ($0.9M) in FY 2026 to ($2.3M) in FY 2031. [13] This loss is due to the exemption from conveyance tax for the transfer of any property with a county-owned deed restriction created under the new provisions. [13]
capital_expenditure_impact: The bill appropriates funds out of the dwelling unit revolving fund for fiscal year 2025-2026 for infrastructure projects. [14] The Committee on Ways and Means recommends an appropriation amount of $20,000,000 (HB740_SD2_SSCR1659_.htm.txt) into the Dwelling Unit Revolving Fund for this purpose. [15] The sum appropriated shall be expended by the Hawaii housing finance and development corporation. [14]
fiscal_implications_after_6_years: The Act is repealed on January 1, 2031, which sunsets the program and its direct fiscal obligations. [14] However, any deed restriction recorded against a property under the program shall run with the land in perpetuity, binding all future owners, successors, and assigns. [14] The conveyance tax exemption and associated revenue loss is estimated to continue, with an impact of ($2.3M) in FY 2031. [13]
updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: A new appropriation of $20,000,000 (HB740_SD2_SSCR1659_.htm.txt) from general revenues to the Dwelling Unit Revolving Fund is recommended for infrastructure projects in FY 2025-2026, separate from the ADU program's funding. [15] [15] The Department of Taxation has provided specific six-year general fund revenue loss projections due to a new conveyance tax exemption, ranging from ($0.9M) in FY 2026 to ($2.3M) in FY 2031. [13] The Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation provided a new assumption that the program's annual $2,000,000 (HB740_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) allocation could enroll about 17 properties per year. [13] The measure now includes new policy exemptions from state laws regarding environmental impact statements (chapter 343), conveyance tax (chapter 247), and the procurement code (chapter 103D). [14] [14]
